description: First attested in 1644. Perhaps a back-formation from abomination. Alternatively, perhaps from Late Latin abōminātus, past participle of abōminarī (“to deprecate as an ill omen”), from ab + ominari (“to forebode, presage”), from omen.

adjectives.description: abominate (comparative more abominate, superlative most abominate)

entries.meaning: (rare) Abominable; detested. [First attested in the late 16th century.]

verbs.description: abominate (third-person singular simple present abominates, present participle abominating, simple past and past participle abominated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To feel disgust towards; to loathe or detest thoroughly; to hate in the highest degree, as if with religious dread. [First attested in the mid 17th century.]
(transitive, colloquial) To dislike strongly. [First attested in the late 19th century.]
